content.description: Start as Dave's Diagonal, but instead of traversing left move up and slightly right on a tricky flake. Layback the flake and find what feet you can-awkward. Some small pinch holds are on the steep face to the left of the flake. Shorter folks may have to layback using more of the little holds on the face while taller climbers may use both the intermittently positive flake and the holds while making a couple cruxy rock on moves. Pretty darn sequential  either way. Finish with steep climbing on slightly lichenish slopers.
content.protection: 3 bolts. A bit scary. 1st bolt is quite high. Getting to third and anchors is more than a bit sporty. Definitely verging on PG on the pro overall, and some pretty full value moves away from the immediate vicinity of the bolts. Nothing really to hit though.
content.location: Sledgehammer NW face. 3rd sport route from left on face. Shares start with Dave's Diagonal. Thanks Brent has its own anchor.

climbs.name: Seismic Line
climbs.fa: Brent Kertzman, Monte Carlson, Tim Fitzgerald 1982 Ground up

content.description: Some what of a Bouldery slab start gets you to nice crystal pulling and a few thought provoking feet. Get a nice rest before a short run out section with good white crystal pinching. This should bring you to the short but steep headwall up top. Expect steep short section on small positive crystals and again, not so good feet. Short and thin brings you to the anchors on top.
content.location: Furthest bolted line left when facing sledgehammer west face.

content.description: Climb thru the bulge to right of Over The Rainbow into a left facing open book.  Then on to the summit via Over The Rainbow.
content.protection: Use anchors for Over The Rainbow

content.description: This route climbs the rightward arching crack on the south side of the crag.  Work back left on slab above.
content.protection: 1 set of stoppers, 1 set of RPs, Cams to 2"

climbs.name: I Think I'm Going To Hurle

content.description: This route follows a prominent dike on the east face of Sledgehammer.  Follow the obvious line through 6 bolts to a fixed anchor.  This is very well protected and has fun moves. Start on fun bouldery beginning. Enjoy the fun face climbing on good crystals and some smears. The crux comes towards the top as you go through a small bulge with tiny crystals and a committing smear.
This route climbs the bolted arete on the southwest cornerof the crag.

climbs.name: Dave's Diagonal
climbs.fa: Dave Larsen, Brad Rognile, Brent Kertzman

content.description: Busse and Burr lists this as a 5.6 mixed route, but the way we went today makes this a purely sport route. Since the gear options seemed marginal, I am guessing that the path described here is going to be the more common way to climb this. Step off the boulder or ascend the somewhat lichenish slab- climber's choice. Work your way up to the quite high 1st bolt of Thanks Brent. Extend that bolt or bolt two of Thanks Brent and work left. Clip two more bolts on A Lady, a Gentleman, and BK's bolt line as you head for that route's anchors.
content.protection: 3 or 4 bolts. BB lists trad pro- Purple C3-#0.4, nuts, micro-nuts
content.location: Sledgehammer NW face. Shares a start with Thanks Brent and shares an anchor with A Lady, a Gentleman, and BK.

climbs.name: A Lady, a Gentlemen, and BK
climbs.fa: Brent and Nora Kertzman & Mike Miller 1995 ground up

content.description: Starts on the Bouldery left to right dihedral feature. Likely the crux from here catch a couple of great rests following up the bolts on great crystals. Great warm up for the area.
content.location: Second sport line from left on NW face

content.description: Sledgehammer has a very high concentration of routes on it.  It almost feels like a giant boulder, but all routes need to be roped.  Routes range from very well protected bolted routes, to trad routes, to bold non-protected face climbing.  Fixed anchors are available for most climbs.
